The Syriac Gazetteer: Encoding Guidelines and TEI P5 Customization

This version of the encoding guidelines for The Syriac Gazetteer were drafted in 2025 by David A. Michelson, William L. Potter, and Daniel L. Schwartz. These guidelines are part of an ongoing community effort to develop uniform good practice in describing geographic data using TEI XML. These guidelines remain under development and contributions are welcome via pull requests or issues submitted to the GitHub repository hosted by Syriaca.org. They are licensced under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International license. Users may cite the guidelines in this way: David A. Michelson, et. al., eds. The Syriac Gazetteer: TEI P5 Customization and Encoding Guidelines (Syriaca.org: 2025), https://github.com/srophe/Gaddel/blob/main/documentation/schemas/syriacaPlaces.odd.

1. The Syriac Gazetteer: Encoding Guidelines and TEI P5 Customization

1.1. Introduction

Welcome to the encoding guidelines for the third edition of The Syriac Gazetteer (hereafter TSG). TSG is a geographical reference work published by Syriaca.org: The Syriac Reference Portal for places relevant to Syriac studies. These guidelines describe the methodology used to create TEI XML files for encoding Syriac geographic data according to the schema implemented by Syriaca.org. We have chosen to use the TEI guidelines because they allow a high level of detail, citation of sources, and flexibility for representing prose data. We anticipate that this schema can be easily adapted for other historical gazetteers and we invite comments and suggestions for improvement.

1.2. Acknowledgements

This present document reuses and adapts from material published published by the Text Encoding Initiative as TEI: Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange in the P5 release, version 4.9.0 as updated on 24th January 2025 (revision f73186978). The TEI guidelines are reused here under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License.

The present document is also an update to previous documentation published by Syriaca.org. An initial schema and documentation for the first edition of The Syriac Gazetteer was designed in 2012-2014 by Thomas Carlson, Tom Elliott, David A. Michelson, Winona Salesky, and Daniel L. Schwartz. In 2019, David A. Michelson, William L. Potter and Michelle P. Taylor prepared written documentation for the second edition of TESG. Portions of the documentation from the first two editions have been reused below under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International license. The current document represents guidelines for the third edition of The Syriac Gazetteer.

In addition, prose and examples have been reused from David A. Michelson, “Using Linked Open Data to Model Cultural Heritage Information: The Research Questions and Data Structures of the Syriaca.org Knowledge Graph,” in Linked Open Data for the Ancient Mediterranean: Structures, Practices, Prospects, edited by Sarah E. Bond, Paul Dilley, and Ryan Horne, ISAW Papers 20 (2021), http://hdl.handle.net/2333.1/69p8d8cc and from David A. Michelson, et. al., eds. Syriac Manuscripts in the British Library: TEI P5 Customization and Encoding Guidelines for Manuscript Description (Syriaca.org: 2024), https://github.com/srophe/britishLibrary/blob/main/documentation/schema/Syriacamsdesc.html under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International license.

1.3. General Editorial Principles

1.3.1. The Seven Core Entities of the Syriaca.org Data Model

The Syriac Gazetteer (TSG) was conceived as part of a larger project to produce reference works (authority files) for the field of Syriac studies. The Syriaca.org data model is designed around identifying and describing seven core conceptual entities relevant to historical research:

  • Places, e.g., the city of Edessa (URI: http://syriaca.org/place/78)
  • Persons, e.g., the author Ephrem the Syrian (URI: http://syriaca.org/person/13)
  • Literary Works, e.g., The Life of Abraham Quidounaya by Ephrem the Syrian (URI: http://syriaca.org/work/567)
  • Bibliographic Items (modern publications), e.g., Robert Murray, Symbols of Church and Kingdom (1975) (URI: http://syriaca.org/cbss/M8NJIL53)
  • Subject Headings (thematic keywords related to Syriac Studies), e.g., “asceticism” (URI: under development)
  • Manuscripts, e.g., British Library Manuscript Add. 14,451 (URI: under development)
  • Material Artifacts, e.g., the Edessene Mosaic of Orpheus Taming Wild Animals (URI: under development)

For each of the above entities, Syriaca.org's primary goal is to publish ‘authority files’, e.g. reference works which establish a unique identifier for each person, place, primary source text, bibliographic citation, keyword, manuscript, and material artifact relevant to the field of Syriac studies. The format of the identifier is a URI, a technical specification which is described in more detail below; see Assigning Place URIs (Uniform Resource Identifiers). In these authority files, each entity is an individual abstract concept identified by a unique URI. For example, the person known as Ephrem the Syrian is identified by the URI: http://syriaca.org/person/13 and the city of Edessa where he spent much of his life is identified as http://syriaca.org/place/78. The necessity of using unique strings of characters instead of traditional names arises from the occurrence of homonymous entities. For example, TSG has entries for more than 50 different churches and monasteries each with the name ‘Mar Gewargis’ (St. George). Accordingly, all Syriaca.org URIs are unique—each identifying only one conceptual entity. Thus, every ‘Church of Mar Gewargis’ is assigned a separate URI.

Syriaca.org URIs are not merely random strings of text and numbers; they are HTTP URIs, meaning that each URI is also a URL (a Uniform Resource Locator, e.g. an HTTP address). Thus, Syriaca.org’s URI for Ephrem the Syrian, http://syriaca.org/person/13, is also a valid HTTP address. The benefit of using HTTP URIs is that these URIs are ‘self-descriptive’ in that each URI is also an HTTP link to a web document describing or defining the concept identified by the URI. Although perhaps obvious to state, the web document which is returned from a Syriaca.org URI is only a definition of the concept named by the URI, not the entity itself (thus the address http://syriaca.org/place/78 does not allow one to download the real-world city of Edessa, but a web page describing that city!).

In the Syriaca.org data model, each URI represents a conceptual thing with a mental existence related to, but not reducible to, its historical or physical manifestation. Syriaca.org adopted this broad definition so that mythological and other ahistorical persons, places, and concepts can be assigned URIs. For example, the concept identified by the URI http://syriaca.org/person/13 identifies not only the historical person Ephrem the Syrian, but also the supra-historical hagiographical and pseudepigraphal traditions about him. Following this same logic, any historical concept can be described in the Syriaca.org URI model, even if its historical existence was only in the cultural imaginary.

TSG is the Syriaca.org publication dedicated to describing places and is responsible for assinging URIs to individual place entities in the Syriaca.org data model. Descriptions of places in TSG can also refer to URIs for any of the seven entities, thus a TSG record for a particular place may define that place in relation to other places, as well as to persons, bibliography, etc. In each instance, these relationships will be encoded in the TSG record as references to Syriaca.org URIs. Taken as a whole, the entire Syriaca.org dataset of linked URIs forms a "knowledge graph" or a map of relationships between URIs from the seven core entitites. In the example of Ephrem the Syrian (http://syriaca.org/person/13) and the city of Edessa (http://syriaca.org/place/78) the relationship between these two entities is part of the Syriaca.org knowledge graph.

1.3.2. The Concept of Place in TSG

TSG is a geographical reference work (in library science terms, an ‘authority file’) published by Syriaca.org to identify and describe places relevant to Syriac studies. The concept of distinct place is the distinguishing criterion for each entry in TSG. Each record in TSG represents a single place that can be disambiguated from other places. Each place is a unique conceptual entity with a mental existence related to, but not reducible to, its physical manifestation. The purpose of each record (and thus each XML file) is to provide information which describes the place identified with that record.

1.3.2.1. Assigning Place URIs (Uniform Resource Identifiers)

Each place in TSG is assigned a unique indentifier. Because place names can be overlapping, ambiguous, or homonymous, this unique indentifier is the essential element of every TSG record. Both users and the database itself rely on this identifier to disambiguate place records.

The format of identifier used in TSG is that of a URI (Uniform Resource Identifier), a technical standard established by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C). In TSG, the URIs have the following format: http://syriaca.org/place/{\d+} (where {\d+} signifies a unique string of digits). For example, the city of Edessa is assigned the following URI: http://syriaca.org/place/78. Syriaca.org URIs are not merely random strings of text and numbers; they are HTTP URIs, meaning that each URI is also a URL (a Uniform Resource Locator) that can be used as a web address leading to a file which provides a definition of the entity associated with the URI.

Or in simple terms, TSG assigns the unique URI http://syriaca.org/place/78 as an ID number for the concept of the city of Edessa, but that URI is also a working URL which will load the TSG record describing the city of Edessa (see https://syriaca.org/place/78).

In each TSG record, this URI is encoded in an <idno> element toward the end of the XML document. For a discussion of how to endcode the assigned URI as an <idno> element, see the documentation section below on Identifiers (<indo>) .

1.3.2.2. Scope of TSG

In terms of including places in TSG, the editors interpret the scope of “places relevant to Syriac Studies” in a maximal rather than restrictive sense, thus TSG is meant to include places named in Syriac texts (such as Ḥarqel — ܚܪܩܠ), places of interest to scholars who work on Syriac history and culture (such as Dura-Europos), places where scholarship on Syriac is being produced (such as Japan), and contemporary places relevant to the modern Syriac heritage communities. There are no chronological or spatial constraints on what may be included in TSG. At least in theory, any type or size of place could be represented in the geographic database, from large empires to single churches or a particular named city gate. Map coordinates are provided for some places, but the database also includes places which are not located or even locatable. Mythological and other ahistorical places are also included in the database.

1.3.3. Bibliographic Citation Requirement

Bibliographic citation is an essential and required element for every entry in TSG.

The intellectual contribution and purpose of TSG is to establish URIs to compile and connect data from previous scholarship on the topic of Syriac Studies. Accordingly, our editorial policy assumes that our records will be primarily composed of information cited from primary and secondary sources. As a reference work, TSG is not intended as a venue for the first publication of original research. In general, our default editorial position will be to accept scholarly consensus and the results of existing scholarship as published. It is not within the scope of TSG to systematically review and correct past scholarship in the field. Nevertheless, authors of TSG records should not knowingly reproduce errors in previous scholarship. In the rare cases in which they are needed, encoding conventions for marking incerta, errata and corrigenda with regard to past scholarship are discussed below; see Certainty.

1.3.3.1. Function of ‘Works Cited’

Each TSG record must include a list of ‘Works Cited’ at the end of the record. This bibliographic list will be visually presented as numbered footnotes on the record webpage and labelled as ‘Works Cited’. This list is NOT intended to be a general bibliography related to the place described and thus should only include works actually cited in the record. (The editorial work of gathering and classifying a general bibliography related to specific places falls within the scope of The Comprehensive Bibliography on Syriac Studies rather than TSG).

A technical discussion of how to encode bibliographic items into the ‘Works Cited’ section is given below, see ‘Works Cited’ (<bibl>).

1.3.4. Customization of the TEI Guidelines

When considering the TEI XML schema created for TSG, it is essential to note that we have customized these guidelines specifically for use in digitally encoding geographic data related to the field of Syriac studies. Due to this specialized use, these guidelines do not include all possible TEI XML features which might be employed for history or geography data in general. Moreover, because the main language of TSG is English, these guidelines assume that each file will designate English as its main language.

We have written the guidelines below with the assumption that the resulting XML files for the The Syriac Gazetteer will be displayed using the custom Gaddel App developed by Syriaca.org and The Digital Lab at Vanderbilt University. We have also made an effort to ensure (as much as possible) that our data will be easily serialized to conform to the data model developed by the Pleiades project, a community-built gazetteer for the field of ancient studies, and to the Pelagios Network's implementation of Linked Open Data principles.

For a more detailed discussion of the data model and architecture of Syriaca.org, readers are encouraged to consult the following technical publication: David A. Michelson, “Using Linked Open Data to Model Cultural Heritage Information: The Research Questions and Data Structures of the Syriaca.org Knowledge Graph,” in Linked Open Data for the Ancient Mediterranean: Structures, Practices, Prospects, edited by Sarah E. Bond, Paul Dilley, and Ryan Horne, ISAW Papers 20 (2021), http://hdl.handle.net/2333.1/69p8d8cc.

1.4. Syriaca.org Encoding Conventions (Applies to Multiple Elements)

This section describes encoding conventions which can be employed with a number of different elements. In particular these conventions are used with the following elements, unless otherwise specified: <desc>, <event>, <location>, <placeName>, <quote>, <relation>, and <state>.

1.4.1. Recording Language Information (xml:lang)

The language of an element's textual contents, such as that of a name variant, should be explicitly recorded using an xml:lang attribute. The contents of this attribute should be an ISO 639 Language code. Syriaca.org employs the two-character ISO 639-1 codes where possible, e.g. ‘en’ rather than ‘eng’. If no two-character code is available, use a three-character code from ISO 639-2 or ISO639-3. For textual contents in the Syriac language, Syriaca's convention is to use ‘syr’ rather than ‘syc’ to avoid confusion over distinguishing "Classical Syriac". For more on language code usage, see Syriaca.org Documentation: Language and Script Identifiers.

Explict tagging of language codes using xml:lang attributes is required on the following elements: <placeName>, <desc>, and <note> as in the following examples:
<placeName xml:lang="syr"  xml:id="name78-13" source="#bib78-14">ܡܕܝܢܬܐ</placeName> <desc xml:lang="en">  <quote source="#bib78-1">183. Edessa</quote> </desc> <note xml:lang="en" type="incerta"  resp="http://syriaca.org">GEDSH article identifies its river as the Balikh, but the identification is contested.</note>
Finally, in some instances a <desc> or <note> element may contain content in multiple languages, such as an English description that includes a Syriac place name that is transcribed, rather than transliterated. In such cases, the language of the majority of the textual contents should be used as the xml:lang of the containing element. The portions of text in a different language should be tagged with a <foreign> element, indicating that its contents are in a ‘foreign’ language from the perspective of the containing element. The <foreign> element should have its own xml:lang attribute whose contents are the ISO 639 langauge code corresponding to the language of its contents, as seen in the following example:
<desc xml:lang="en">Attestation of name <foreign xml:lang="syr">ܐܘܿܪܫܠܹܡ</foreign> in a note in <title>Jerusalem, Saint Mark's Monastery, Ms. 181 [HMML SMMJ 00181]</title>.</desc>
This use of the <foreign> element, moreover, enables the HTML view to more precisely display content with bidirectional text (i.e., a mixture of right-to-left and left-to-right writing systems).

1.4.2. Recording Date Information for Occurrences and Durations

In certain cases, contributors may wish to provide information about the temporal limits of a particular piece of information about a place. For example, the duration of a given settlement's existence, or the date on which a historical event occurred. Date information for these cases is provided by one or more of the following attributes: when, from, to, notBefore, and notAfter. These attributes can be used to qualify a <event> or <state> element with temporal information. To record a date for an event that occurred at a particular point in time, use the when attribute:
<event type="other" when="0201"  source="#bib78-1">  <desc xml:lang="en">Flood of the river <placeName ref="http://syriaca.org/place/191">Daiṣan</placeName> destroyed part of city.</desc> </event>
Durations in time, on the other hand, must use either a from/to or notBefore/notAfter attribute pair depending on the certainty of the date range. The use of from/to attributes represents a date range with a high degree of certainty, whereas uncertain or approximate date ranges should be expressed with notBefore/notAfter attributes. The latter is more common for historical events, so is the preferred method.
<event type="other" notBefore="1913"  notAfter="1919" source="#bib78-1">  <desc xml:lang="en">Massacres of some of Armenian and Syriac Christians during World War I.</desc> </event>

The values of these temporal attributes must be expressed as a date following the ISO 8601 Date and Time format, that is YYYY-MM-DD, i.e. the year followed by month followed by day. In most cases, however, only the year can or should be included, e.g. ‘1014’. For dates prior to the year 1000, leading zeroes must be supplied to ensure a four-digit year, e.g. ‘0751’, ‘0010’, ‘0004’. Positive year values express dates in the Common Era (CE); for earlier dates, use a negative year value: ‘-0450’ corresponds to 450 BCE (this practice corresponds to the W3C standard XML Schema Part 2: Datatypes Second Edition.

For more information on the use of dates within Syriaca.org, including guidelines for approximating date ranges for imprecise or uncertain ranges, see the Syriaca.org Dating Conventions document.

1.4.3. Sources and Attribution of Intellectual Credit

When encoding child elements nested within <place>, TSG records are required to cite their sources using either the source or resp attributes. These attributes can be placed on any of these elements: <desc>, <event>, <location>, <placeName>, <quote>, <relation>, and <state>.

Whenever possible, the editorial policy of TSG is that all information in a record should have citations to bibliographic references found in the ‘Works Cited’ section of the record. Citations should be made using source as described below in Inserting Bibliographic Citations (source). In rare cases, editors of TSG may provide attribution information not sourced to a primary or secondary source using the resp attribute as described below; see Asserting Information without a Source (resp). The use of source and resp are mutually exclusive. Editors should use resp only when it is not possible to use source.

1.4.3.1. Inserting Bibliographic Citations (source)

Use of the source attribute is a method for pointing to a bibliographic item found in the ‘Works Cited’ section of the XML document. Before using source, editors must first encode an entry for the bibliographic item using the <bibl> element and a assign it an ID as described in the documentation section ‘Works Cited’ (<bibl>).

Once a <bibl> element for the item has been created, citations to that same bibliographic item can be inserted (and repeated) almost anywhere in the place record. These citations are inserted using the source attribute which is permitted on the following elements: <desc>, <event>, <location>, <placeName>, <quote>, <relation>, and <state>. For example, the source of a place name would be indicated by a source attribute of the <placeName> element. Here is a specific example for the place of Edessa (URI https://syriaca.org/place/78) which has the modern name "Urfa":
<place>  <placeName source="#bib78-1">Urfa</placeName>  <desc>...</desc>  <bibl xml:id="bib78-1">   <ptr target="http://syriaca.org/cbss/C5T777C3"/>   <citedRange unit="p">138-139</citedRange>  </bibl> </place>
In this example, Edessa’s modern name ‘Urfa’ is given on the authority of an article in GEDSH. The citation is made by linking the <placeName> and <bibl> elements by use of the bibl's xml:id "bib78-1" supplied as an anchor (i.e., prefixed with a #) in a source attribute on the <placeName> element: source="#bib78-1".
It is also possible to cite multiple sources for the same element. In these cases, the value of the source attribute is the xml:id for each source, with a prefixed #, and delimited by spaces. For example, the name ‘Edessa’ is attested in multiple separate sources, so that fact can be encoded as follows
<placeName xml:id="name78-1"  source="#bib78-1 #bib78-2 #bib78-6 #bib78-23">Edessa</placeName>
The addition of multiple citations for the same piece of information is, in general, not necessary or even recommended. When it occurs in TSG it is often the result of the bulk importing of data. As an editorial practice for individual authors, a single source is all that is required (and recommended) for most information. When multiple sources are listed in a single source attribute, they should be sorted in ascending order based on the second numeric value in the xml:id, as demonstrated in the example above (-1, -2, -6, -23, etc.).

1.4.3.2. Indicating Direct Quotations

Direct quotations are indicated in TSG according to two different methods: transcription using <placeName> and quotation using <quote>.

1.4.3.2.1. Transcribing Place Names (<placeName>)

Transcriptions of name variants should be collected and encoded in <placeName> elements as a direct child of the <place> element. These <placeName> elements must include a citation (using source) and their contents are be defintion interpreted to be verbatim quotations, with no further markup needed. See the discussion above concerning Inserting Bibliographic Citations (source). For more on supplying name variants in TSG entries, see below under Place Names (<placeName>)

1.4.3.2.2. Reporting Direct Quotations (<quote>)

In all other instances, direct quotations should be encoded by use of the <quote> element. The opening and closing of the <quote> element should mark the start and conclusion of the quotation. There is no need to use quotation marks in addition to the <quote> element. Quotation marks will be auto-generated and added to the HTML view of the record. All <quote> elements must include a citation (using source) following the method described above concerning Inserting Bibliographic Citations (source).

1.4.3.3. Asserting Information without a Source (resp)

In rare cases, editors of TSG supply information not sourced to a primary or secondary source. To ensure that even this information is attributable to a source, elements that should be sourced but are otherwise lacking a source attribute should receive a resp attribute with the value ‘http://syriaca.org’ to indicate that the editors of the TSG are responsible for the inclusion of the information:
<desc type="abstract" xml:lang="en"  resp="http://syriaca.org">A city of <placeName ref="http://syriaca.org/place/124">Mesopotamia</placeName>, the capital of the ancient kingdom of <placeName ref="http://syriaca.org/place/145">Osrhoene</placeName>, modern Urfa.</desc>
In the preceding example, a concise description of Edessa was composed by a contributor to the place record, indicated by the use of the resp attribute in place of a source attribute.

1.4.4. Linking Persons, Places, Works, and Bibliography to Syriaca.org URIs

As discussed above in the section The Seven Core Entities of the Syriaca.org Data Model, one of the distinctive features of TSG is its integration with the Syriaca.org knowledge graph through the use of URIs to identify and link persons, places, literary works, and bibliography. For each of these entity types, Syriaca.org has published an ‘authority file’ which assigns a URI or Uniform Resource Identifier to every unique entry. Besides TSG (the geography authority file), these authority files include The Syriac Biographical Dictionary, The New Handbook of Syriac Literature, and the Comprehensive Bibliography on Syriac Studies.

In the TSG, it is possible to link to Syriaca.org URIs within the following descriptive elements: <desc>, <quote>, or <note>. Use of Syriaca.org URIs to identify prose allusions to persons, places, works, etc. is strongly encouraged whenever possible. It should be noted that the use of Syriaca.org URIs in these sections is for descriptive purposes (i.e. relating the subject of the TSG record to other places, persons, etc.). The inclusion of URIs in these cases does NOT assign a URI to the place record. For that separate function, see the section below: Identifiers (<indo>).

1.4.4.1. Allusions to Persons (<persName>/ref)

References to persons can appear in <desc>, <quote>, or <note> elements (including when these are children of <location>, <event>, <state>). In these cases, these persons should be linked to Syriaca.org URIs.

When a TSG record refers to a person who has a Syriaca.org URI, the mention of a personal name should be tagged using the <persName> element and linked to the URI using ref. The Syriaca.org person URI should be first confirmed as valid in the Syriac Biographical Dictionary. In the following example, the place Tagai (http://syriaca.org/place/1475) is identified based on its relationship to a person:
<desc type="abstract" xml:lang="en"  resp="http://syriaca.org" corresp="http://syriaca.org/geo">A location with a monastery whose inhabitants received a letter from <persName ref="http://syriaca.org/person/51">Severus of    Antioch</persName>.</desc>

Because the URI and not the personal name serves as the identifier, it is not necessary to use a ‘preferred form’ of the personal name. If the allusion is a quotation, the encoder should leave the wording as found in the original.

Person URIs should be attached only to direct references to persons. When a personal name occurs as part of a title of a work (e.g. The Homilies of John Chrysostom) or as part of a place name (e.g. The Convent of Mar Isaac), these entities should be treated as works or places respectively. In these cases the prose is marked with a <title> or <placeName> element instead and the personal name must not be tagged nor person URIs attached.

1.4.4.2. Allusions to Places (<placeName>/ref)

References to places can appear in <desc>, <quote>, or <note> elements (including when these are children of <location>, <event>, <state>). In these cases, these places should be linked to Syriaca.org URIs.

When descriptive prose in a TSG record refers to a place that has a Syriaca.org URI, the mention of the place should be tagged using the <placeName> element and linked to a URI.

Nota Bene: The <placeName> element is used in two ways in TSG. This present section refers only to the secondary use of <placeName> elements in marking up prose descriptions in TSG with URIs. The primary use of the <placeName> element is to collate place name variants related to a TSG entry. For the name variant use case of <placeName> please see the Place Names (<placeName>) section below.

All <placeName> elements used in this secondary, descriptive usage are required to have a ref attribute which points to a Syriaca.org place URI. In the following example, the settlement Gazarta (http://syriaca.org/place/88) is identified based on its relationship to three other places:
<desc type="abstract" xml:lang="en"  resp="http://syriaca.org" corresp="http://syriaca.org/geo">A city on the <placeName ref="http://syriaca.org/place/202">Tigris river</placeName> between <placeName ref="http://syriaca.org/place/8">Amida</placeName> and <placeName ref="http://syriaca.org/place/139">Mosul</placeName>.</desc>

Places URIs should be attached only to direct references to places. When a personal name occurs as part of a title of a work (e.g. The Chronicle of Edessa) or as part of a personal name (e.g. Jacob of Edessa), these entities should be treated as works or persons respectively. In these cases the prose is marked with a <title> or <persName> instead and the geographic epithet must not be tagged nor place URIs attached.

1.4.4.3. Allusions to Literary Works (<title>/ref)

References to texts or literary works can appear in <desc>, <quote>, or <note> elements (including when these are children of <location>, <event>, <state>). In these cases, these works should be linked to Syriaca.org URIs.

When a TSG record refers to a literary work that has a Syriaca.org URI, the title or mention of the work should be tagged using the <title> element and linked to the URI using the ref attribute.

Nota Bene: At present Syriaca.org's authority file for literary works is incomplete, so not all works may have available URIs.

In the following example, the church of Mar Thomas the Apostle (http://syriaca.org/place/2593) is identified based on its relationship to a primary source. relationship to three other places:
<desc type="abstract" xml:lang="en"  source="#bib2593-1 #bib2593-2" corresp="http://syriaca.org/geo">A church in Edessa where the coffin of <persName ref="http://syriaca.org/person/2123">Thomas the Apostle</persName> was placed, according to a tradition recorded in the <title ref="http://syriaca.org/work/8559">Chronicle of Edessa</title>. </desc>

Work URIs should be attached only to direct references to works. When the title of a work occurs as part of a personal name (e.g. Author of The Macarian Homilies) or in a yet unidentified case where a work title might occur as part of a place name, these entities should be treated as persons or places respectively. In these cases the prose is marked with a <persName> or a <placeName> instead and the work title must not be tagged nor work URIs attached. It is also useful to distinguish between a ‘work’ and a ‘bibliographic item’. The former is an abstract concept (The Chronicle of Edessa, URI: http://syriaca.org/work/8559), while a bibliographic item refers to a specific instance of a publication (e.g. Guidi's 1902 edition, URI: http://syriaca.org/cbss/63ZKDBEH).

1.4.4.4. Allusions to Bibliographic Items (<bibl>/<ref>/target) -- Planned Implementation

The encoding feature below has not yet been implemented but is planned for the future.

References to Bibliographic Items can appear in <desc>, <quote>, or <note> elements (including when these are children of <location>, <event>, <state>). In these cases, these items should be linked to Syriaca.org URIs.

Nota Bene: The <bibl> element is used in two ways in TSG. This present section refers only to the secondary use of <bibl> elements in marking up prose descriptions in TSG with URIs. The primary use of the <bibl> element is to create the individual entries for the ‘Works Cited’ section for a TSG record. For the ‘Works Cited’ use case of the <bibl> element please see the ‘Works Cited’ (<bibl>) section below.

In addition: This feature is currently not implemented in TSG.

When the title of secondary biblographic items (books, articles, etc.) are mentioned, they can be tagged with the <bibl> element. The bibliographic item may be linked with a CBSS URI by using a child <ref> element with the URI placed in a target attribute of the <ref> element. Note the distinction here in the use of a <ref> element rather than a ref attribute as used for linking URIs for persons, places, or literary works as described above.

In the following example, a <note> on the settlement Ayn Dābā (http://syriaca.org/place/434) includes a scholarly discussion of a modern translation:
<note xml:lang="en" type="errata"  resp="http://syriaca.org">  <bibl>   <ref target="http://syriaca.org/cbss/SGBVKKGH">Dolabani's Syriac      translation</ref>  </bibl> erroneously identifies this place with <placeName ref="http://syriaca.org/place/9">Anazarba</placeName>. </note>

1.5. Record Structure

This section presents the TEI XML elements and structures required or permitted in each record. For the most part, the description here follows the order in which the elements will occur in the record ("document order").

1.5.1. The TEI Root Element (<TEI>)

Every record begins with the <TEI> root element. This element contains the same attribute values in every TSG record. These values will be document elsewhere on the Syriaca.org documentation page. The <TEI> root element must always contain the same two child elements: <teiHeader> and <text>. As noted above, the main language of TSG is English, so the <TEI> root element must include an xml:lang attribute with a value of ‘en’.

1.5.2. The TEI Header (<teiHeader>)

The <teiHeader> element contains metadata about title, authorship, copyright, and licensing of the data in the record. The <teiHeader> in TSG records follows the universal guidelines for all Syriaca.org publications. These guidelines will be documented elsewhere on the Syriaca.org documentation page.

1.5.3. Place Description (<place>)

1.5.3.1. Occurance of the <place> Element in the Record

The geographic data in each TSG record is contained in a series of nested elements expressed by following XPath /TEI/text/body/listPlace/place. Thus the structure of every document will include the following:
<TEI xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">  <teiHeader/>  <text>   <body>    <listPlace>     <place>...</place>    </listPlace>   </body>  </text> </TEI>

The <listPlace> element must contain a <place> element and may contain a <listRelation> element. Except for information about related entities, all geographic data is encoded in a single <place> element.

Insert sentence about how each record only has one place element.

This <place> element must have type and ana attributes.

The <place> element can contain the following elements in this order, some of which are required (indicated by *):

  • <placeName>* (see Place Names)
  • <desc>* (see Abstracts)
  • <location> (see Locations)
  • <event> (see Event Types)
  • <state> (see Status Types)
  • <note> (see Notes)
  • <idno>* (see Identifiers)
  • <bibl>* (see ‘Works Cited’ (<bibl>))

1.5.3.2. Place Type Classification (type and ana)

Each place record in TSG must be classified according to a taxonomy of place types maintained by Syriaca.org. This taxonomy derives from a subset Pleiades Vocabulary of Place Categories for use in the TSG. The place type should be supplied in the type attribute of the <place> element. As well, a Syriaca.org Taxonomy URI corresponding to the place type should be included in the ana attribute of the <place> element:
<place type="settlement"  ana="http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/settlements">...</place>
The following place types, their corresponding URIs, and a brief description of their scope is provided in the following table:
Place Type Values, URIs, and Descriptions
Type Value (type)URI (ana)Description
buildinghttp://syriaca.org/taxonomy/buildingsA construction for which there is no narrower category, such as a church or mosque. Examples of this type include palaces and named city gates.
churchhttp://syriaca.org/taxonomy/churchesA building for Christian religious services. It can be a parish church, a monastic church, a cathedral, or a small chapel used only occasionally, but not a chapel that is part of a larger church.
compositehttp://syriaca.org/taxonomy/compositeA named place concept which merges multiple distinct place types, such as a city and a diocese. More specific types are preferred.
designated-spacehttp://syriaca.org/taxonomy/designated-spacesAn area with artificial boundaries which is not necessarily built up, such as a cemetery, town square, or polo ground.
diocesehttp://syriaca.org/taxonomy/diocesesAn ecclesiastical province governed by a bishop, archbishop, or metropolitan.
fortificationhttp://syriaca.org/taxonomy/fortificationsA military outpost such as a fort or a castle.
islandhttp://syriaca.org/taxonomy/islandsA land-mass smaller than a continent surrounded on all sides by water.
madrasahttp://syriaca.org/taxonomy/madrasasA building or space designated for instruction in the Islamic sciences.
monasteryhttp://syriaca.org/taxonomy/monasteriesA whole monastic complex, including living quarters for the monks or nuns, the church(es), and potentially a refectory, library, school, or other part.
mosquehttp://syriaca.org/taxonomy/mosquesA building or designated space used for Muslim congregational prayers. It can be part of a larger building complex.
mountainhttp://syriaca.org/taxonomy/mountainsAn elevated physical feature, from Mt. Ararat down to a prominent hill.
natural-featurehttp://syriaca.org/taxonomy/natural-featuresA natural feature for which there is no narrower category, such as a mountain or open water. Examples of this type include forests and hot springs.
open-waterhttp://syriaca.org/taxonomy/open-waterA broad category for seas, lakes, oceans, and ponds.
parishhttp://syriaca.org/taxonomy/parishesAn ecclesiastical region below a diocese, presided over by a priest.
provincehttp://syriaca.org/taxonomy/provincesA political unit subject to a "state" but larger than a city. States often have multiple levels of administrative units (e.g. the late Ottoman vilayets, sanjaks, kazas, and nahiyes), all of which can be indicated as a "province."
quarterhttp://syriaca.org/taxonomy/quartersA subdivision of an urban center.
regionhttp://syriaca.org/taxonomy/regionsA term indicating a geographic extent larger than a city, without a corresponding politico-administrative apparatus. The size could range from a small valley to an entire continent.
riverhttp://syriaca.org/taxonomy/riversA stream of water of whatever size, from the smallest creek to the Amazon. Wadis are also included, even if they are not filled with water year-round.
settlementhttp://syriaca.org/taxonomy/settlementsAny collection of civilian residences, from the smallest village to the largest metropolis.
statehttp://syriaca.org/taxonomy/statesA sovereign government such as an empire, kingdom, caliphate, or independent emirate.
synagoguehttp://syriaca.org/taxonomy/synagoguesA building designated for use in Jewish worship.
templehttp://syriaca.org/taxonomy/templesA building designated for use in pagan worship.
unknownhttp://syriaca.org/taxonomy/unknownA place whose name is known, but what sort of place it represents is unknown.

1.5.3.3. Place Names (<placeName>)

This element is required. A record may have any number of <placeName> elements.

Place names are essential for identifying and disambiguating individual places. Every record must have at least one <placeName> element, and may have any additional number of <placeName> elements. The text node of this element should contain a name by which the place is or was known. Multiple name variants can be added; each should be in a separate <placeName> element. Name variants may be recorded for any language, and that language should be recorded as described in the Recording Language Information (xml:lang) section. Each record must have at least one place name in English or English transliteration indicated as the headword. If necessary, the author may craft a prose description as a place name when a location does not have a more traditional name (for example, ‘Villa near Sycae’, URI: http://syriaca.org/place/2860, identifies a location based on a prose description in a primary source.

Additionally, <placeName> elements must have a unique xml:id attribute of the form name\d+-\d+. The first digits derive from the numerical portion of the Syriaca URI for the place, and the latter is a sequential integer:
<placeName xml:id="name78-6" xml:lang="ar"  source="#bib78-4">الرها</placeName>
Finally, as seen in the preceding example, all <placeName> elements must indicate the source of the name form as detailed in the Inserting Citations section of these Guidelines.
1.5.3.3.1. Syriaca Headwords
At least one <placeName> element must be tagged as a Syriaca Headword using a srophe:tags attribute with the value of ‘#syriaca-headword’. As the headwords are used as preferred labels and for alphabetization in search/brose results, at least one English place name should be tagged as a headword. At most one headword per language may be defined.
<placeName source="#bib78-2 #bib78-5"  xml:id="name78-1" xml:lang="en"  srophe:tags="#syriaca-headword"    xmlns:srophe="https://srophe.app">Edessa</placeName> <placeName xml:id="name78-2" xml:lang="en"  source="#bib78-2 #bib78-5 #bib78-7">Urfa</placeName> <placeName resp="http://syriaca.org"  xml:id="name78-3" xml:lang="syr"  srophe:tags="#syriaca-headword">ܐܘܪܗܝ</placeName>

1.5.3.4. Abstracts (<desc>)

An English-language abstract is required. A record may have any number of additional <desc> elements.

Every record must have an abstract, i.e. a short description or one to two lines of prose describing the place. The purpose of the abstract is to help users of TSG to easily disambiguate search results and quickly identify the place for which they are searching. For places which also have entries in the electronic edition of Gorgias Encyclopedic Dictionary of the Syriac Heritage (GEDSH), TSG has reused the abstracts from GEDSH (this is done with permission and through verbatim quotation and citation). Ideally, an abstract should be at least one sentence in legnth, but in the case of some very well known places, the abstracts quoted from GEDSH are simply an entry number and phrase. Every record must have an abstract written in English. It is also possible to add additional abstracts in other languages. Additionally, individual sub-volumes of TSG may have their own, distinct abstracts.

The abstract is encoded in a <desc> element with a type attribute whose value is "abstract":
<desc type="abstract" xml:lang="en"  resp="http://syriaca.org"  corresp="http://syriaca.org/geo http://syriaca.org/johnofephesus http://syriaca.org/johnofephesus/places"> A city of <placeName ref="http://syriaca.org/place/124">Mesopotamia</placeName>, the capital of the ancient kingdom of <placeName ref="http://syriaca.org/place/145">Osrhoene</placeName>, modern Urfa. </desc>
Abstracts may be included in languages other than English, and each abstract must have its language recorded as described in the Recording Language Information (xml:lang) section, above
Abstracts must also have a corresp attribute that contains one or more space-separated URIs that correspond to the <idno> element in the <seriesStmt> elements. These URIs identify TSG and its sub-volumes, such as the Gazetteer to John of Ephesus’s Ecclesiastical History. If there are multiple abstracts, only one can reference a given series URI, and every series URI must be referenced by one of the abstracts. In the following example, the URIs of three <seriesStmt> elements are referenced by two abstracts:
<TEI xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">  <teiHeader>   <fileDesc> ... <seriesStmt>     <title level="s" xml:lang="en">The Syriac Gazetteer</title> ... <idno type="URI">http://syriaca.org/geo</idno>    </seriesStmt>    <seriesStmt>     <title level="s" xml:lang="en">A Guide to John of Ephesus</title> ...    <idno type="URI">http://syriaca.org/johnofephesus</idno>    </seriesStmt>    <seriesStmt>     <title level="m" xml:lang="en">Gazetteer to John of Ephesus’s          Ecclesiastical History</title> ... <idno type="URI">http://syriaca.org/johnofephesus/places</idno>    </seriesStmt>   </fileDesc>  </teiHeader>  <text>   <body>    <listPlace>     <place> ... <desc type="abstract" xml:lang="en"       resp="http://syriaca.org"       corresp="http://syriaca.org/johnofephesus http://syriaca.org/johnofephesus/places"> A city of <placeName ref="http://syriaca.org/place/124">Mesopotamia</placeName>, the capital of the ancient kingdom of      <placeName ref="http://syriaca.org/place/145">Osrhoene</placeName>,            modern Urfa.</desc>      <desc xml:lang="en"       corresp="http://syriaca.org/geo">       <quote source="#bib78-5">a famous city, five day journey eastward from       <placeName ref="http://syriaca.org/place/18">Aleppo</placeName>,              now called Urfa.</quote>      </desc> ... </place>    </listPlace>   </body>  </text> </TEI>
Abstracts that derive from primary or secondary sources should include a citation of their source. In addition to the general guidelines on Inserting Citations, abstracts should use the following conventions. If the abstract's content is paraphrased from one or more sources, a source attribute should be added directly to the <desc> element:
<desc type="abstract" xml:lang="en"  source="#bib55-3"  corresp="http://syriaca.org/geo http://syriaca.org/johnofephesus http://syriaca.org/johnofephesus/places"> An Anatolian coastal region north of Antioch. </desc>
If the abstract is, instead, a direct and exact quote from a source, the <desc> element should include a child <quote> element that contains the source attribute and text contents of the abstract:
<desc type="abstract" xml:lang="en"  corresp="http://syriaca.org/geo">  <quote source="#bib78-5"> A famous city, five day journey eastward from  <placeName ref="http://syriaca.org/place/18">Aleppo</placeName>, now called    Urfa. </quote> </desc>

The preceding examples have shown that <desc> elements allow several child elements useful for marking up entities that may appear in the abstract's contents. See Linking Persons, Places, Works, and Bibliography to Syriaca.org URIs, above, for guidelines on using these elements.

1.5.3.4.1. Additional Descriptions (<desc>)
As noted above, only one abstract per language and volume of TSG is permitted. Additional concise descriptions may be included. These descriptions follow the same encoding guidelines as abstracts, except they should not include the type or corresp attributes:
<desc xml:lang="syr-Syrj">  <quote source="#bib78-3">ܡܕܺܝܢܬܐ ܗܳܝ ܛܒܝܒܬܳܐ ܠܡܰܕܢܚܳܐ ܕܚܳܠܳܒ ܚܰܡܫܳܐ ܝܰܘܡ̈ܝܢ    ܘܡܶܫܬܰܡܗܐ ܝܰܘܡܳܢ ܐܘܪܦܰܗ̈</quote> </desc>

1.5.3.5. Physical Location (<location>)

This element is not required. A record may have any number of <location> elements.

Physical location information for a place record can be encoded within one or more <location> elements. Each <location> element should be sourced as described in the guidelines on Inserting Citations. TSG permits two kinds of location information, geographic coordinates and relative locations. Locations based on geographic coordinates should precede relative locations.

1.5.3.5.1. Geographic Coordinates
Locations with geographic coordinates must include a type attribute with a value of ‘gps’. The geographic coordinates should be recorded in a child <geo> element. Coordinates must be formatted as latitude then longitude, separated by a space:
<location type="gps" source="#bib78-2">  <geo>37.15 38.8</geo> </location>
When there are multiple <location> elements for geographic coordinates, i.e. type of ‘gps’, a subtype attribute must also be supplied. One of the <location> elements must have a subtype attribute with ‘preferred’, and all of the others must have the value of ‘alternate’. This convention enables the Gaddel web application to know which coordinates to use when loading the map view for this place record's HTML page. See the below example:
<location subtype="preferred" type="gps"  source="#bib78-2">  <geo>37.15 38.8</geo> </location> <location subtype="alternate" type="gps"  source="#bib78-15">  <geo>37.1453862000 38.7838840000</geo> </location>
1.5.3.5.2. Relative Locations
Some primary or secondary source descriptions locate a place relative to another location. Such situations may be encoded within a <location> with a type attribute whose value is ‘relative’. An example of a relative location follows:
<location type="relative">  <desc xml:lang="en">   <quote source="#bib78-5">    <measure unit="days-journey"     quantity="5">five day journey</measure>    <offset>eastward from</offset>    <placeName ref="http://syriaca.org/place/18">Aleppo</placeName>   </quote>  </desc> </location>
The <location> should contain a <desc> element with language tagging using an xml:id attribute. If the location statement is a direct quote from a source, a <quote> element should be used, otherwise sourcing information may be provided directly on the <desc> element. The components of the relative location can be marked up using several elements. A <measure> element, with unit and quantity attributes, are used to tag the expression of the distance between the place record and its relative location. The unit attribute's value is not constrained and should correspond to the element's text contents, converted to lowercase with whitespace replaced by hyphen (-) characters. A directional indication, or other modifier (e.g., 'near', overlooking') may be encoded as an <offset> element. Finally, the name of the place from which the relative location is measured should be encoded as a <placeName> element with a ref attribute containing its Syriaca URI, if applicable. Note that the order of these elements can vary and should follow the flow of the prose content in the <desc> element.

1.5.3.6. Events (<event>)

This element is not required. A record may have any number of <event> elements.

1.5.3.6.1. Attestations in Primary Sources (<event>)
Attestations of place names or the presence of confessional communities at a place that appear in historical primary sources may be recorded within an <event> element with a type attribue whose value must be "attestation". Attestations must include an xml:id of the pattern attestation\d+-\d+, where the first sequence of digits is the numerical portion of the place URI and the second is a sequential integer. This identifier is used to link the attestation to the names or confessions it describes. Attestations must also be sourced as detailed in the guidelines on Inserting Citations. The following example includes both kinds of attestations:
<event type="attestation"  xml:id="attestation78-1" notBefore="1146" notAfter="1234"  source="#bib78-9">  <desc xml:lang="en"> Attestation of name <foreign xml:lang="syr">ܐܘܪܗܝ</foreign> in the anonymous <title ref="http://syriaca.org/work/113">Chronicle of 1234</title>. </desc>  <link target="#name78-3 #attestation78-1"/> </event> <event type="attestation"  xml:id="attestation78-2" when="1146" source="#bib78-9">  <desc xml:lang="en"> Attestation of Syrian Orthodox church in Edessa in the    anonymous <title ref="http://syriaca.org/work/113">Chronicle of      1234</title>. </desc>  <link target="#confession78-1 #attestation78-2"/> </event>
As the example shows, each attestation contains a human-readable description of the historical attestation in a <desc> element, whose language must be indicated as described in Recording Language Information (xml:lang). The description may contain additional markup, as described in Linking Persons, Places, Works, and Bibliography to Syriaca.org URIs. Additionally, the attestation must include a <link> element with a target attribute containing anchors connecting the attestation's xml:id value and the xml:id of the attested place name or confession. Finally, the attestation's <event> element may include dating information as described in the Recording Date Information for Occurrences and Durations section.
1.5.3.6.2. Historical Events (<event>)
The <event> element is also used to indicate events which happened to a place, such as being founded, being destroyed, or anything else. Such uses of the <event> element must have type of "other", to distinguish the use of this element from attestations. Examples of two possible uses for an event follow:
<event type="other" when="-0304"  source="#bib78-1">  <desc xml:lang="en">Renamed Edessa by Seleucus I Nicator.</desc> </event> <event type="other" when="0201"  source="#bib78-1">  <desc xml:lang="en">Flood of the river <placeName ref="http://syriaca.org/place/191">Daiṣan</placeName> destroyed part of    city.</desc> </event>
As seen in the above example, <event> elements used for historical events differ from those used for attestations in only a few ways. First, they do not require an xml:id. Second, they should not include a <link> element. Otherwise they are constructed in the same way, with source information following the guidelines for Inserting Citations; a child <desc> element containing additional markup of named entities as applicable (see Linking Persons, Places, Works, and Bibliography to Syriaca.org URIs); and attributes for dating events (see Recording Date Information for Occurrences and Durations).

1.5.3.7. Historical Status (<state>)

This element is not required. A record may have any number of <state> elements.

The TEI Guidelines uses the <state> element to encode data on the status of places. TSG uses the <state> element to encode two types of status: religious confessions and existence.

1.5.3.7.1. Confessional Presence (<state>)

Some places, such as churches or monasteries, have declared religious identities. Other places, such as cities, may be home to representatives of multiple different religions. Still other places, such as rivers or mountains, have no particular confessional identity in themselves, although they may be venerated particularly by adherents to one or more religions.

The presence of a confessional community in a place, or otherwise connected with a place, is recorded in a <state> element with type of "confession". Multiple confessions for a particular place, or even disjoint durations of the same confession, are indicated by multiple <state> elements. Confession assertions must be identifed with an xml:id whose value follows the pattern confession\d+-\d+, where the first sequence of digits is the numerical portion of the place URI, and the latter is a sequential integer to uniquely identify the <state> element. The particular confessional community must be identified both with a human-readable label and a machine-readable URI derived from The Syriac Taxonomy. The former is provided as the text contents of a child <desc> element, with xml:lang of "en". The latter must be supplied in a ref attribute on the <state> element. Permitted values for URIs and labels may be found in the following table:

Religious Confession URIs and Labels
Syriaca Taxonomy URI (ref)Human-readable Label (<desc>)
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/ancient-church-of-the-eastAncient Church Of The East
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/anglicansAnglicans
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/arabic-christiansArabic Christians
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/arabic-protestantsArabic Protestants
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/armenian-catholicsArmenian Catholics
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/armenian-chalcedoniansArmenian Chalcedonians
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/armenian-christiansArmenian Christians
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/armenian-orthodoxArmenian Orthodox
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/armenian-protestantsArmenian Protestants
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/assyrian-evangelical-churchAssyrian Evangelical Church
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/audiansAudians
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/bardaisanitesBardaisanites
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/borboritesBorborites
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/buddhistsBuddhists
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/chaldean-catholic-churchChaldean Catholic Church
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/chaldean-syrian-churchChaldean Syrian Church
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/christiansChristians
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/church-of-the-eastChurch Of The East
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/coptic-christiansCoptic Christians
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/east-syrian-churchEast Syrian Church
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/ebionitesEbionites
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/elchasaitesElchasaites
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/ethiopic-christiansEthiopic Christians
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/georgian-christiansGeorgian Christians
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/gnosticsGnostics
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/greek-catholicsGreek Catholics
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/greek-christiansGreek Christians
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/greek-orthodoxGreek Orthodox
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/indian-christiansIndian Christians
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/ismailiIsmaili
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/jewish-christiansJewish Christians
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/jewsJews
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/karaitesKaraites
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/kharijiKhariji
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/latin-christiansLatin Christians
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/malabar-catholic-churchMalabar Catholic Church
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/malabar-independent-syrian-churchMalabar Independent Syrian Church
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/malankara-catholic-churchMalankara Catholic Church
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/malankara-orthodox-syrian-churchMalankara Orthodox Syrian Church
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/malankara-syriac-orthodox-churchMalankara Syriac Orthodox Church
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/mandeansMandeans
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/manichaeansManichaeans
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/mar-thoma-syrian-churchMar Thoma Syrian Church
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/marcionitesMarcionites
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/marditesMardites
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/maronitesMaronites
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/melkitesMelkites
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/muslimsMuslims
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/ophitesOphites
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/pagansPagans
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/quqitesQuqites
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/rabbaniteRabbanite
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/roman-catholicsRoman Catholics
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/rum-orthodoxRum Orthodox
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/russian-orthodoxRussian Orthodox
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/sadduceesSadducees
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/samaritansSamaritans
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/shiaShia
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/sunniSunni
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/syriac-christiansSyriac Christians
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/syrian-catholicsSyrian Catholics
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/syrian-orthodoxSyrian Orthodox
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/twelverTwelver
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/west-syrian-churchWest Syrian Church
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/yezidisYezidis
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/zaydiZaydi
http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/zoroastriansZoroastrians
The following is an example of a properly-encoded confession state:
<state type="confession"  xml:id="confession78-1"  ref="http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/syrian-orthodox" from="0451" to="1924" source="#bib78-1">  <desc xml:lang="en">Syrian Orthodox</desc> </state>
The above example also demonstrates that confession states should be sourced according to the guidelines on Inserting Citations. As well, confessions may optionally include attributes to express temporal constraints on the assertion of the presence of a confessional community in a place as described in Recording Date Information for Occurrences and Durations. In the preceding example, the from and to attributes indicate that Syrian Orthodox communities were present at Edessa between 451 and 1924 CE.
1.5.3.7.2. Existence and Duration (<state>)
Assertions of the existence of a place, and the duration of that existence, are made using a <state> element with a type of "existence". These elements require source information following the guidlines for Inserting Citations. At the most basic level, this element asserts that a place has existed, or continues exist. Example:
<state resp="http://syriaca.org"  type="existence"/>
The duration of a place's existence can be qualified using the temporal attributes described in the Recording Date Information for Occurrences and Durations section.
<state resp="http://syriaca.org"  type="existence" from="0306" to="2013">  <precision match="@from" notAfter="0306"/>  <precision match="@to" notBefore="2013"/> </state>

Technical Note: This use of the <precision> element was added to the TEI guidelines by the TEI consortium at the request of Syriaca.org for the specific use cases described above. Additional documentation can be found (as of 2018) at TEI Feature Request [#519] and The TEI Discussion List.

1.5.3.8. Scholarly Annotation (<note>)

This element is not required. A record may have any number of <note> elements.

TSG employs the <note> element for two different purposes: deprecation of a name variant and the encoding of information that is uncertain or incorrect.

All <note> elements must have an xml:lang attribute indicating the language of the note. In most cases this will be "en" for English but other languages can be indicated as needed. (for more details, see Recording Date Information for Occurrences and Durations).

1.5.3.8.1. Deprecated Names (<note>)

Certain names reported in our database are patently erroneous (e.g. ܛܘܪܳܐ ܕܩܰܐܣܒܘܢ for ‘Mount Qāsiyūn’, URI: http://syriaca.org/place/518, instead of ܛܘܪܳܐ ܕܩܰܐܣܝܘܢ (in this case the error is based on the translator mis-reading an Arabic letter ba for ya). We need to preserve these erroneous names in our data for historical reasons, so that the right place can be found as a search result even if someone searches on the basis of an erroneous print resource or now deprecated name. Nevertheless, the editors do not wish to assert implicitly or explicitly that this is an "acceptable alternate" form of the name. In order to mark the <placeName> element as erroneous, we create a <note> element with a type=‘deprecation’. The content of the <note> is then a detailed explanation of why this name is considered problematic. In order to link the <note> to the appropriate <placeName>, an target attribute whose value is the xml:id values for the deprecated <placeName> is included in the <note> separated by whitespace if there are links to multiple names for the same reason in the note. TEI Guidelines do not allow <note> elements before <desc>, <location>, <event>, or <state> elements, so the <note> indicating the deprecation should occur immediately before the <idno> section.

Such names are visually marked in the html display of the place record, taken out of the list of names and instead listed in the Deprecations section at the bottom of the record, to warn users that these forms are problematic.

Example:
<placeName xml:id="name496-3"  xml:lang="syr-Syrj" source="#bib496-1">ܦܰܢܺܝܗ</placeName> ... <note target="#name496-3" xml:lang="en"  type="deprecation" resp="http://syriaca.org"> Dolabani or his printer dropped off the first consonant of the name. </note>
1.5.3.8.2. Disputanda (<note>)

As with the inclusion of deprecated it is sometimes necessary to report in a place record information which is either known to be incorrect or which is contested in the scholarly literature. In these cases, editors should signal this information with a <note> element before the <idno> element(s). The content of the <note> is the description of the problematic assertion, using as non-combative a formulation as possible and avoiding naming living scholars to avoid multiplying scholarly contention. The <note> can have type="incerta" if it is reporting scholarly uncertainty or disagreement about an assertion, or type="corrigenda" for typographical errors or other equally mechanistic problems which can be easily fixed. The type="errata" should only be used for <note> elements if there is a clear and undisputed error whose solution is not obvious.

Consider the examples below, drawn from different places:
<note xml:lang="en" type="incerta"  resp="http://syriaca.org"> GEDSH article identifies its river as the <placeName ref="http://syriaca.org/place/43">Balikh</placeName>, but the identification is contested. </note>
<note xml:lang="en" type="corrigenda"> In Dolabani's translation of Barsoum's description <quote xml:lang="syr-Syrj">ܒܓܰܪܓܪܰ</quote> should read <quote xml:lang="syr-Syrj">ܒܓܰܪܓܰܪ</quote>. </note>
<note xml:lang="en" type="corrigenda"  resp="http://syriaca.org"> GEDSH Map II displays the location too far to the south, east of <placeName ref="http://syriaca.org/place/91">Ḥama</placeName> rather than west of <placeName ref="http://syriaca.org/place/18">Aleppo</placeName>. </note>
<note xml:lang="en" type="corrigenda"  resp="http://syriaca.org"> Moosa's English translation of Barsoum's description was incorrectly published under the headword "Samosata," while his description under the headword "Arsamosata" in fact describes the village <placeName ref="http://syriaca.org/place/442">Kaʿbiya</placeName>. </note>
<note xml:lang="en" type="errata"  resp="http://syriaca.org"> Barsoum's description erroneously merges the information for this location with that of the other <placeName ref="http://syriaca.org/place/571">Mor Bosus</placeName>, which is located between Apamea and Ḥomṣ. </note>

1.5.3.9. Identifiers (<idno>)

This element is required. A record must have at least one <idno> indicating a Syriaca.org URI. Records belonging to more than one Syriaca.org publication, must have an <idno> for each publication. A record may have any number of additional <idno> elements.

As discussed above in the section on the Concept of a Place, URIs are an important part of delineating a place. Each place record needs one or more <idno> elements to indicate the URIs which refer to this place. Each <idno> element will have a type attribute with value "URI", and the first should encapsulate the Syriaca.org URI for the place: http://syriaca.org/place/{\d+}. Other <idno> elements with type="URI" will encapsulate any Pleiades URI for this place as well as any Wikipedia URL(s) which refer to this place. In particular, if the same place is the topic of separate Wikipedia articles divided by time period, both or all such articles will have their URLs listed here. If desired, a link to a DBpedia resource URI can be encapsulated within an <idno> element of type="URI", but care should be exercised only to link to the DBpedia resource URI when the place is the subject of only one Wikipedia article, and when the type of place described by that article is the same as the type of place in our database (it is very common for Wikipedia articles to be about a modern country rather than a historical region, for example, or for village Wikipedia articles found in modern Turkey to be about "a district" rather than about the village itself). If there is any doubt that the DBpedia resource URI and the Syriaca.org URI are speaking of an identical place in all contexts, it is better to omit the DBpedia URI.

The URIs of Edessa (one from Syriaca.org, one from Pleiades, and two different Wikipedia articles) can be represented as follows:
<idno type="URI">http://syriaca.org/place/78</idno> <idno type="URI">http://pleiades.stoa.org/places/658457</idno> <idno type="URI">http://syriaca.org/johnofephesus/places/78</idno> <idno type="URI">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edessa</idno> <idno type="URI">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Şanlıurfa</idno>

1.5.3.10. ‘Works Cited’ (<bibl>)

This element is required. A record must have at least one <bibl> element documenting the existence of the place as a concept. A record may have any number of additional <bibl> elements.

Syriaca.org manages the publication information for all citations in a separate reference work, The Comprehensive Bibliography on Syriac Studies (CBSS). Accordingly, the first step in adding a citation into a record in TSG is to identify the corresponding entry in CBSS. Users can search the bibliography at https://syriaca.org/cbss/search.html. Once the item to be cited is located, authors should note the URI for the bibliographic item. This URI will have the format http://syriaca.org/cbss/[A-Z0-9]{8}$ (where [A-Z0-9]{8}$ signifies a unique string of 8 uppercase alphanumeric characters). For example, the URI for J.B. Segal, Edessa, ‘The Blessed City’ (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1970) is http://syriaca.org/cbss/FQCVBMNS. If the desired bibliographic item is not found in CBSS, authors should request the creation of an entry in CBSS.

After ascertaining the CBSS URI, the next step is add an entry for that item in the ‘Works Cited’ section of the place record in TSG. Each bibliographic item cited should be marked up as a separate <bibl> element. The purpose of the <bibl> element is to provide three linking functions:
  • to the footnote number
  • to the CBSS URI for the cited item
  • to the specific page numbers or other cited range within that item
Here is an example of a <bibl> record:
<bibl xml:id="bib78-24">  <ptr target="http://syriaca.org/bibl/FQCVBMNS"/>  <citedRange unit="p">82-87</citedRange> </bibl>

In this example the <bibl> has a unique xml:id which is required and is used to identify the citation internally in the ‘Works Cited’ list for the place record. The attribute value for the xml:id is in the format bib{\d+}-{\d+}, where the first number is derived from the Syriaca.org URI for the place (i.e. using the final unique numeric element in the URI) and the second number is a sequential integer representing the order of this <bibl> element in the series of <bibl> elements contained in this place record, beginning from 1. In this example, the twenty-fourth <bibl> element within the place record describing Edessa (URI https://syriaca.org/place/78) leads to the following xml:id value "bib78-24". The second numeric value (in this case "24") will also serve as the number for the footnote in the HTML view of the record.

Next the example above illustrates how the <bibl> also has a required <ptr> (pointer) element which provides the link externally to the CBSS URI, encoded as a target attribute value. In this case the URI is http://syriaca.org/bibl/FQCVBMNS. An automated script will use this URI link to insert the full publication information into the HTML view of the TSG record.

Lastly, this example above indicates a specific page range using the optional but recommended <citedRange> element (and its required unit attribute). This cited range indicates ranges specific to the citations in this place record. If a place record contains multiple citations of the same bibliographic item, the cited ranges must all be combined into a single ascending cited range (for example "82-87, 90, 95-96"). Unfortunately, it is not possible to separate out more specific citations at this time.

Allowed values for unit are:

Allowed Citation Range Unit Values
Unit ValueDescription
booka book, typically a numbered portion of an ancient work
chaptera chapter by number, title, or both
cola column or column range
entryan entry in a collection such as an reference work
figa figure, i.e. a graphic, table, etc.
fola folio number or folio range
linea line number or line range
mapa map
notea footnote or endnote
parta part of a book or collection, i.e. chapter and verse of a biblical text
pa page number or page range
sectiona section of a text
URLa URL where information is located
vola volume of a multi-volume work

These values remain the same even if the cited range is plural. When multiple page numbers are cited, they should be entered in full and never be abbreviated (thus "556-558" not "556-8").

All of these <bibl> elements should be grouped together as the final child elements within the <place> element, as in this example:
<place>  <placeName>...</placeName>  <desc>...</desc>  <bibl xml:id="bib78-1">   <ptr target="http://syriaca.org/cbss/C5T777C3"/>   <citedRange unit="p">138-139</citedRange>  </bibl>  <bibl xml:id="bib78-2">   <ptr target="http://syriaca.org/cbss/P8KQJ7AE"/>   <citedRange unit="map">Map I B1, II B1, III</citedRange>  </bibl>  <bibl xml:id="bib78-3">   <ptr target="http://syriaca.org/cbss/SGBVKKGH"/>   <citedRange unit="p">556-558</citedRange>  </bibl> </place>
Each <bibl> element in this ‘Works Cited’ section should be unique in that no two <bibl> elements should point to the same Syriaca.org CBSS URI.

In as much as is feasible, the <bibl> elements should be ordered based on the order of occurance of citation in the XML file. Thus the first bibliographic item to be cited would occur as the first <bibl> and the second item to be cited would occur as the second <bibl>, etc. At times, however, this order will not be strictly maintained. For example, if the first item to be cited is also cited again later in document, it would remain as the first <bibl> and does not need to be repeated. Simiarly, if a later revision of the record introduces citations of new bibliographic items in the middle of the record, authors should add the new bibliographic items below the existing <bibl> elements rather than attempting to re-order or re-number the <bibl> elements according to occurence. Nota bene: In these cases, the auto-generated footnote numbering used on the webpages for TSG entries will not follow standard numeric order (e.g., a reference to footnote 7 might precede the reference to footnote 6) but the citation numbers will nevertheless direct readers to the correct work cited.

1.5.4. Related Places

This element is not required. A record may have any number of <relation> elements.

TSG uses the <relation> element (which appear inside a <listRelation> element immediately following the <place> element). The <relation> element must have a type attribute with one of the following values: "see-also", "disambiguation", or "contained-with".

Common to all <relation> elements is a child <desc> element offering a human-readable version of the relationship. See below for examples.

1.5.4.1. Disambiguating Places

This relationship is when an encoder things users might be confused between the identity of two places. There are four distinct kinds of scenarios for place disambiguation: places that share a name, conceptually related places, co-located places, and places easily confused for one another.

TSG uses a URI from the Syriac Taxonomy to indicate which of these types of disambiguation is appropriate. This appears at the value of a ref attribute. The values are as follows:

Disambiguation Values
DisambiguationValue on the ref Attribute
Places that Share a Namehttp://syriaca.org/taxonomy/share-a-name
Conceptually Related Placeshttp://syriaca.org/taxonomy/conceptually-related
Co-located Placeshttp://syriaca.org/taxonomy/co-located
Places Easily Confusedhttp://syriaca.org/taxonomy/not-to-be-confused-with

For all of the disambiguation relationships, the <relation> element requires a mutual attribute. A mutual attribute takes two place URIs.

1.5.4.1.1. Places That Share a Name

There are many places that share a name. Syriaca.org only assigns URIs to distinct entities so when there are two place records it can be assumed that the editors are confident in the existence of two places. However, it is helpful for users to to find the specific place they are looking for if they have easy access to multiple records for places that share a name.

<relation type="disambiguation"  ref="http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/share-a-name"  mutual="http://syriaca.org/place/32 http://syriaca.org/place/717" resp="http://syriaca.org">  <desc xml:lang="en">This place shares a name with one or more distinct    places.</desc> </relation>
1.5.4.1.2. Conceptually Related Places

TSG distinguishes between place types. This can get confusing when different place types are closely related conceptually. For example, a city gives its name to a diocese even though the diocese has a very different geographic footprint than that city. They are two entities but closely related. Our sources can also talk about regions in rather vague ways that do not correspond entirely to the geo-political entity with which it shares a name. For this reason, we distinguish between a region and a political province. See the code example below.

This relationship has not yet been implemented in TSG.

1.5.4.1.3. Co-located Places

This relationship is used to help distinguish between two places that can be confused based on closely sharing a location.

<relation type="disambiguation"  ref="http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/co-located"  mutual="http://syriaca.org/place/2407 http://syriaca.org/place/791 http://syriaca.org/place/207" resp="http://syriaca.org">  <desc xml:lang="en"> This place shares a location with one or more distinct    places that should not be confused with one another. </desc> </relation>
1.5.4.1.4. Places Easily Confused

This relationship is perhaps the most general. It can be used to distinguish between entities that have been confused in the scholarly literature or might be confused by users for any reason.

<relation type="disambiguation"  ref="http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/not-to-be-confused-with"  mutual="http://syriaca.org/place/509 http://syriaca.org/place/111" resp="http://syriaca.org">  <desc type="note" xml:lang="en"> Not the same conceptual place as <placeName ref="http://syriaca.org/place/111">Kashkar</placeName>. </desc> </relation>

1.5.4.2. Places Contained Within Places

This relationship is used to indicate that a place is contained within another place. It can be used for a church inside a city or a city inside a province.

For a containment relationship, the <relation> element must take an active and a passive attribute instead of a mutual attribute. The URI for the place contained is the value of the active attribute and the URI for the place containing it is the value of the passive attribute.

<relation type="contained-within"  ref="http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/broader" active="http://syriaca.org/place/758"  passive="http://syriaca.org/place/90" source="#bib758-1">  <desc xml:lang="en">   <placeName ref="http://syriaca.org/place/90">Hakkārī region</placeName>  </desc> </relation>

1.5.4.3. See Also

This relationship is the most generic way of indicating a cross-reference within TSG. It can be used whenever the encoder thinks users might want to look at another record because it is somehow related but that relationship cannot accurately be described using one of the relationships discussed above.

This relationship takes a mutual attribute with two or more place URIs as the value.

<relation type="see-also"  ref="http://syriaca.org/taxonomy/related"  mutual="http://syriaca.org/place/2615 http://syriaca.org/place/1535 http://syriaca.org/place/182 http://syriaca.org/place/58" resp="http://syriaca.org">  <desc xml:lang="en">See also one or more related places.</desc> </relation>

2. The Syriac Gazetteer Schema Customization

2.1. Elements

2.1.1. <TEI>

<TEI> (TEI document) contains a single TEI-conformant document, combining a single TEI header with one or more members of the model.resource class. Multiple <TEI> elements may be combined within a <TEI> (or <teiCorpus>) element. [4. Default Text Structure 16.1. Varieties of Composite Text]
Moduletextstructure — The Syriac Gazetteer Schema Customization
Attributes
  • att.global
    • @xml:id
    • @n
    • @xml:lang
